awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Low Noble Metal Content Catalysts for Emission Control Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the commercialization of more sustainable catalysts for emission control systems. The use of high levels of pure noble metals such as platinum, palladium and rhodium in existing commercial catalysts are increasingly unsustainable in many aspects, including high price, noble metal scarcity, low recycling recovery, and limited global supply, posing significant challenges to catalyst manufacturing. Manufacturing low-cost and efficient catalysts for commercial applications in emission control systems will enable more cost effective adherence to clean air and other environmental regulations. The low-noble metal content catalysts are anticipated to reduce the content of noble metals in the catalysts in comparison with existing catalysts in many emission control systems, reducing the cost of emission control systems.  There is a clear market potential for the catalyst technology in view of the expectation of the global market of emission control system catalysts.

This I-Corps project focuses on customer discovery in the translation of a new catalyst technology to commercial production of low-noble-metal-content catalysts for emission control systems.  Noble metals such as palladium and platinum are widely used in the catalysts for emission control systems, including factory exhaust gas treatment reactors and catalytic converters, to meet the ever-tightening of emission standards, calling for further reduction of emission levels of the criteria gaseous pollutants.  However, the high costs and market volatility risks associated with the platinum group metals constitute a major area of pain in the market of emission control systems.  To address this challenge, the proposed low-noble-metal-content catalysts feature noble metals alloyed with non-noble transition metals in nano-alloy and composite formulations, which exhibit enhanced catalytic activity and stability for the elimination reactions of the pollutants at significantly reduced use of noble metals in comparison with existing catalysts in the commercial emission control systems.  Insights into the competitiveness of the catalyst technology in the emission control catalyst market will be developed through the intensified activities of customer discovery in this project.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this I-Corps project was to conduct customer discovery aiming at the commercialization of sustainable catalysts for emission control systems in both mobile and stationary segments. There is an increasingly stringent emission regulation due to global concerns over the environmental pollution and air quality. The use of high levels of pure noble metals, such as platinum, palladium and rhodium (the so-called platinum group metals (PGM)), in existing commercial catalysts for emission control systems such as catalytic converters, are increasingly unsustainable in many aspects, including high and fluctuating price, noble metal scarcity, low recycling recovery, and limited global supply.  This problem poses significant challenges to catalyst manufacturing, calling for manufacturing low-cost and efficient catalysts for commercial applications in emission control systems. Solving this problem will have societal benefits for clean air and environmental sustainability. The low-noble metal content catalysts are anticipated to reduce the content of noble metals in the catalysts in comparison with existing catalysts in many emission control systems, reducing the cost of emission control systems.  There is a clear market potential for the catalyst technology in view of the expectation of the global market of emission control system catalysts to reach about $6 to 16 billion in 5 to 8 years at an estimated CAGR of 5 to 11%.

The major effort in this I-Corps project focused on customer discovery, the results of which were used to determine the viability of translation of a new catalyst technology to commercial production of low-noble-metal-content (or low-PGM) catalysts for emission control systems (see Figure 1).  Indeed, PGM metals are widely used in the catalysts for emission control systems, including factory exhaust gas treatment reactors and catalytic converters, to meet the ever-tightening of emission standards for further reduction of emission levels of the criteria gaseous pollutants.  Major findings in this project showed that the high cost and the market volatility risk associated with the platinum group metals constitute a major area of pain in the market of emission control systems.  The new low-PGM catalysts will address the problem by at least 50% reduction in the use of noble metals in the catalyst formulation with enhanced catalytic activity and stability in comparison with existing catalysts used in the commercial emission control systems.  Moreover, findings from over 300 interviews with potential customers have provided insights into the high competitiveness of the low-PGM catalyst technology in the emission control catalyst market, to which the Team is pursuing the technology transfer and the commercialization potential.


Last Modified: 11/06/2017
Modified by: Chuan-Jian Zhong

Image
  • An illustration of the use of PGM metals in catalysts for emission control systems such as catalytic converters and industrial emission control systems, which eliminate pollutants that are harmful to the environment and human health.
    Shiyao Shan, Jin Luo, and Chuan-Jian Zhong
    Public Domain
    Chuan-Jian Zhong
    Figure 1
